EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Avon Company's (Avon) Zanesville, Ohio facility is a state-of-the-art distribution center that handles 100% of Avon's US distribution and employs 271 people when fully operational. The site has one RMP Program Level 1 covered process designated as Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area (Area) which is subject to the chemical accident prevention regulations under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act and 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) part 68. The covered process has no public receptors within the distance to the endpoint (0.2 miles or 1,056 feet) from a worst-case release and has had no accidents with specific off-site consequences within the past five years.

Avon associates responsible for coordinating health and safety management report directly to the facility's Local Crisis Management Team and the North American Regional Crisis Management Team (North American Corporate Legal and North American Manager, Treasury and Insurance Risk).  By assigning health and safety responsibilities to the associates who are directly involved in the facility's operational areas and reporting directly to senior (local and regional) management, the safety function becomes more effective and sends a clear message that ensuring facility safety is a basic management function and responsibility. While Avon's focus is on protecting people and property, we also work to achieve full compliance with applicable safety and fire protection-related regulations.

THE FACILITY
During the construction of the Zanesville facility, significant portions of the project's capital went directly into designing the facility with Associate safety and property protection in mind. This focus, specifically included the design of the Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area, which was designed and built with the following attributes:

- Labyrinth designed access so that any shrapnel from an explosion cannot escape the room;
- A two-hour rated firewall;
- An in

-rack sprinkler system equipped with eighteen sprinklers per rack section. The system will activate once the temperature reaches 155 degrees Fahrenheit and will release 30 gallons of water per minute.  The sprinkler heads are protected against damage by a cage covering each head.
- An independent overhead sprinkler system for the entire Area, which is triggered to activate at 165 degrees Fahrenheit;
- Exterior doors that are clearly marked to designate the Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area; and 
- A facility-wide fire alarm system.

In addition to the design specifications of the Area, additional ventilation equipment was installed to provide better air flow which will prevent the Area's ambient air temperature from elevating to potentially dangerous levels.

It should also be noted that the facility's fire detection system is connected to the Muskingum County 911 Emergency Directory, which is housed at the Muskingum County Sheriff's Department to ensure a rapid response to an emergency.

AEROSOL CONTAINING MATERIALS HANDLING AND STORAGE POLICY
Avon's M0002 "Aerosol Handling and Storage" Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) addresses the proper receiving, storage, and picking of aerosol containing pallets as well as the material handling equipment, waste management, and employee training requirements associated with the handling of flammable containing aerosols. Components of this policy include, but are not limited to:

- Trucks or trailers carrying aerosol products must be kept away from the building, if possible, at least approximately 15 meters (50 feet).  The doors of the trailer must then be opened to allow the trailer to "air out" for at least 15 minutes before backing up to a loading dock door.
- Move unloaded aerosol pallet loads to the Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area immediately upon being received and processed. Temporary storage of aerosols in the Receiving area is prohibited.
- Once an aerosol pallet has been deli

ble mixture contained within finished products.

For purposes of this plan, it is assumed that the worst-case release scenario would occur outside of the Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area, although the subject products are handled in accordance with the "Handling & Storage of Aerosol Products" Policy and are stored in the specially designed, constructed, and maintained Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area.  

In accordance with the "Risk Management Program Guidance for Warehouses (40 CFR Part 68)", EPA Document 550-B-00-009, dated March 2009, the endpoints of the Aerosol Product Flammable Storage Area were calculated, and the following assumptions were made:  

- The flammable mixture contains 41% butane (CAS 106-97-8), 27% isobutane (CAS 75-28-5), and 17% propane (CAS 74-98-6), based on Avon supplied information.  Worst case scenario and endpoint calculations were based on this ratio as it represents the propellant mixture of the product with the highest on-site inventory at any one time.
- The quantity of the flammable substance released would be released as a vapor cloud.
- A vapor cloud explosion would result from the release.
- No administrative controls or passive mitigation were in place.
- The affected distance was rounded up to the nearest one-hundredth of a mile.
- The largest flammable mixture container was five ounces.
- The explosion took place outside of the Aerosol Product Flammable Mixture Storage Area.

The heat of combustion for the mixture (HCm) was calculated by using the method outlined in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (US EPA 550-B-99-009).  
		
		HCbutane = [(12,775/2.2) / (25,846/2.2)] x 45,719 = 22,597 kJ/kg
		HCisobutane = [(7,750/2.2) / (25,846/2.2)] x 45,576 = 13,666 kJ/kg
		HCpropane = [(5,321/2.2) / (25,846/2.2)] x 46,333 = 9,539 kJ/kg
		HCmixture = (22,597) + (13,666) + (9,539) = 45,803 kJ/kg

The distance that an explosion would travel, from the center

of the explosion, for every 1 psi over container pressure is calculated by the following:

Dmi = 0.0081 x (0.1 x Wlb x (HCf / HCTNT)^1/3

Dmi - Distance to 1 psi overpressure for the quantity released (in miles)
 	
Wlb = Weight of flammable substance (pounds)
HCf = Heat of combustion of flammable substance (kilojoule per kilogram) Heat of combustion value from the Appendix C-1 Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (US EPA 550-B-99-009).  
HCTNT = Heat of explosion of trinitrotoluene (TNT) (4,680 kilojoules per kilogram)

Dmi = 0.0081 x [Heat of Combustion of Mixture] = Endpoint Distance
Dmi = 0.0081 x [0.1 x 25,846 x (45,803/4,680)]1/3 = 0.23 miles = 0.2 miles

This calculation resulted in an endpoint distance of 0.2 miles (1,056 feet) from the point of the release. After an examination of the facility's surrounding land use, within this radius, it was determined that there are no residential populations, public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons/correctional facilities, recreation areas, major commercial, office, or industrial areas), or any environmental receptors.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLANNING
Avon's Zanesville facility has one covered process, designated as the Handling and Storage of Flammable Aerosol Products, that is considered a regulated Program Level 1 process under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provision of 40 CFR 68. This provision requires an applicable facility to develop and implement a Risk Management Program and to coordinate a response plan with local emergency responders for all covered processes that handle or store listed toxic or flammable substances above the threshold quantities.  Additionally, under the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act (Section 302, 311/312) the Zanesville facility is required to notify state and local authorities of the hazardous and extremely hazardous substances stored over a threshold quantity; this notification requirement is satisfied via

the Tier II reports submitted by the facility prior to March 1, annually. These material disclosures assist the state and local authorities when developing their chemical emergency preparedness plans and coordinating response capabilities and communication. Avon's E0001 Environmental Emergency Standard Operating Procedure outlines the facility's response to all anticipated environmental emergency situations as well as identifying its emergency response equipment and contacts.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE COORDINATION
Avon will coordinate with the Muskingum County Emergency Management Agency Director and 911 Coordinator, Mr. Jeff Jadwin and the Washington Township Fire Department Chief, Chief Gene Hanning to ensure both agencies are aware of the characteristics and features of the facility; the flammable materials and quantities being stored; and, that the facility is included in their emergency response planning.  The Washington Township Fire Department has conducted multiple training exercise at the facility, in the past, and have reviewed multiple emergency response scenarios with facility personnel. Additionally, the Washington Township Fire Department representatives visit and tour the facility, at least annually. Avon's S009 Emergency Action Plan Standard Operating Procedure address the facility's response to a variety of emergency situations including severe weather, fire, and evacuation; as well as the roles and responsibilities of Avon personnel in the event of an emergency situation.  

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Avon Zanesville facility has had no accidental releases of the subject flammable mixture in the past five years.

CURRENT STATE OF FACILITY
There are currently no planned changes to the facility that would impact the overall safety of the building.
